description: {"blocks":[{"key":"ahq6q","text":"The purpose of this protocol is to outline the parameters for pathologic and morphologic assessment of human pancreatic tissue. This protocol was developed for tissue specimens prepared via formalin fixation and paraffin embedding by the HuBMAP Tissue Mapping Center at Vanderbilt. It provides a rapid but comprehensive initial assessment, though it should not be considered a substitution for formal pathology analysis. For assessment of gross morphology, please see HuBMAP | VU TMC Eye/Pancreas | Human Pancreas Processing for Multiple Applications.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"bold","offset":468,"length":82}],"entityRanges":[{"key":0,"offset":468,"length":82}],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{"0":{"type":"link","mutability":"MUTABLE","data":{"guid":"6668A5F0C4E211ECAC77372D0CB8D065","url":"https://dx.doi.org/10.17504/protocols.io.bwejpbcn"}}}}

groups.title: Human BioMolecular Atlas Program (HuBMAP) Method Development Community

parent_protocols.title: HuBMAP | VU TMC Eye/Pancreas | Pancreas Pipeline Overview

status.info: We use this protocol and itâ€™s working

steps.step: {"blocks":[{"key":"69mra","text":"Image H\u0026E-stained tissues prepared according to standard protocol using a whole-slide digital scanner (Aperio ScanScope or Zeiss AxioScan) at 20X magnification. Slides may also be reviewed under a light microscope (Olympus Bx41).","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[{"key":0,"offset":26,"length":39}],"data":{}},{"key":"f15fk","text":" ","type":"atomic","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[{"key":1,"offset":0,"length":1}],"data":{}},{"key":"8jg0t","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"ctepa","text":"Download example H\u0026E images (shown in Figures here):  ","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[{"key":2,"offset":53,"length":1}],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{"0":{"type":"link","mutability":"MUTABLE","data":{"guid":"062ABBB1C03511EC86480A58A9FEAC02","url":"https://dx.doi.org/10.17504/protocols.io.rm7vz3e6rgx1/v2"}},"1":{"type":"result","mutability":"IMMUTABLE","data":{"blocks":[{"data":{},"depth":0,"entityRanges":[],"inlineStyleRanges":[],"key":"75qv","text":"Nuclei should stain blue. Cytoplasm of acinar cells should stain pink with blue zymogen granules. The large blood vessels should demonstrate clear differentiation of red blood cells (RBCs) when present, surrounding collagen, and endothelial nuclei with scant cytoplasm.","type":"unstyled"}],"entityMap":{}}},"2":{"type":"file","mutability":"MUTABLE","data":{"forceSelection":true,"guid":"47AB5AC0D0AB11EC8D4449630581E9A5","id":239229,"original_name":"Pancreas Histopathology Assessment_H\u0026E.pdf","placeholder":"","raw_source":"","source":"https://s3.amazonaws.com/protocols-files/files/hjv7bh5qp.pdf"}}}}

{"blocks":[{"key":"4uh6t","text":"Assess and record pathologic and morphologic features using the attached template, reviewing at least one block from each anatomical region of the organ (head, body, and tail). Features listed in the template are described in detail in the following steps. Sub-steps detail further assessment to confirm and/or supplement initial pathology review.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"bold","offset":177,"length":79},{"style":"italic","offset":177,"length":170}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"bgj94","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"2cl46","text":"  ","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"italic","offset":0,"length":1}],"entityRanges":[{"key":0,"offset":0,"length":1}],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{"0":{"type":"file","mutability":"MUTABLE","data":{"forceSelection":true,"guid":"E96B6120C4C611ECAC77372D0CB8D065","id":232636,"original_name":"Pancreas Histopathology Assessment template.xlsx","placeholder":"","raw_source":"","source":"https://s3.amazonaws.com/protocols-files/files/hdf6bh5qp.xlsx"}}}}

(inspissated secretion/stone)","type":"unordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"8567e","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"4l544","text":"Neoplasia: yes or no?","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"bold","offset":0,"length":11}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"16csn","text":"If acinar to ductal metaplasia (ADM), specify number of lobules/lesions and whether it is focal","type":"unordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"357r4","text":"If pancreatic intraepithelial neoplasia (PanIN), specify the grade (1A, 1B, 2, or 3)","type":"unordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"fntl3","text":"If other neoplasia, describe","type":"unordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"ep62m","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"fqb2t","text":"â–·ADM: transformation of acinar cells to duct-like morphology; {"blocks":[{"key":"fd3s0","text":"Evaluate the vasculature:","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"1oc06","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"dt17e","text":"Angiopathy: normal or abnormal?","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"bold","offset":0,"length":12}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"4ff3n","text":"If abnormal, is there evidence of calcification?","type":"unordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"9jlk9","text":"If abnormal, is there arteriosclerosis/arteriolosclerosis?","type":"unordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"6vaov","text":"    If yes, give grade (0-4)","type":"unordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"7h5fj","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"5ecal","text":"Refer to: Ling et al., 2020.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[{"key":0,"offset":10,"length":17}],"data":{}},{"key":"8jts7","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"fuo2n","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"95dgs","text":"    ","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[{"key":1,"offset":0,"length":1}],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{"0":{"type":"link","mutability":"MUTABLE","data":{"guid":"6D9C4730C03911ECAC77372D0CB8D065","url":"https://doi.org/10.1097/mpa.0000000000001664"}},"1":{"type":"image","mutability":"MUTABLE","data":{"guid":"8E9F82E0D08C11EC9C8371E9E5BF5499","height":371.2,"id":239257,"is_video":false,"legend":{"blocks":[{"data":{},"depth":0,"entityRanges":[],"inlineStyleRanges":[{"length":54,"offset":0,"style":"bold"}],"key":"fsc31","text":"Figure 7. Normal and pathologic vascular architecture.","type":"unstyled"}],"entityMap":{}},"mime":"image/png","original_name":"image.png","placeholder":"https://s3.amazonaws.com/protocols-files/files/hjw5bh5qp.jpg","source":"https://s3.amazonaws.com/protocols-files/files/hjw3bh5qp.jpg","type":1,"webp_placeholder":"https://s3.amazonaws.com/protocols-files/files/hjw4bh5qp.webp","webp_source":"https://s3.amazonaws.com/protocols-files/files/hjw2bh5qp.webp","width":580}}}}

{"blocks":[{"key":"j0ru","text":"Use Congo red stain to confirm/differentiate with islet hyaline fibrosis; expect amyloidosis in diabetic and prediabetic individuals (consider A1C and BMI) and in old age.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{}}
